title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" is introduced, which includes an expansion of the deduction for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment specifies limitations on the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction amount is reduced by a certain ratio, with a maximum deduction of $8,000 for 2003 and $12,000 for 2004 and beyond. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is calculated without considering this section. The deduction amount is reduced by a specific ratio determined by the taxpayer's income level. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year, calculated without considering specific sections and after applying certain adjustments. Inflation adjustments are made for taxable years after 2003. For taxable years after 2003, dollar amounts in subparagraph (B)(i)(II) are increased by a cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. Rounding rules apply to adjusted amounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for taxable years after 2003. Rounding rules apply to adjusted amounts. Additionally, the definition of eligible students is clarified. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust dollar amounts for taxable years after 2003, with rounding rules applying to adjusted amounts. The definition of eligible students is clarified by inserting "of eligible students" after "expenses." The term "eligible student" is defined as given in section 25A(b)(3). The amendments made by this section are permanent and effective for payments made in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. SEC. 25C. INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. The tax code allows individuals to claim a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint filers). The credit for interest paid on qualified education loans is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint filers). Modified adjusted gross income excludes certain income sources and is subject to inflation adjustments after 2003. The $50,000 and $100,000 amounts for the education loan interest credit are subject to inflation adjustments after 2003. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $50, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed for dependents. The education loan interest credit amount is subject to inflation adjustments and will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50 if not already. No credit is allowed for dependents, and the credit is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. The education loan interest credit is subject to inflation adjustments and rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed for dependents, and it is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. Definitions for "qualified education loan" and "dependent" are provided, and special rules include denial of double benefit and the requirement for married couples to file a joint return. Married couples must file a joint return to be eligible for the education loan interest credit. Marital status is determined according to section 7703 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred before or after the enactment of this Act, with respect to loan interest payments due after December 31, 2002.
